I urge Members to consider a complet different reaction to the current economic difficulties.

They are a signal that we cannot continue as we are, and that, thanks to borrowing that has been too cheap and imports that have been too cheap, we have all been living above our means and we cannot continue to consume at the same rate.
The adjustment will be painful, but it is necessary. In these hard times, there is another message that is even more salient but will not be heard in these institutions.

That is, the EU cannot continue with its massive legislative programs in the name of health and safety, consumer protection, social equality for instance, because the overriding effect of all these schemes is to add costs and to crush the productive activity on which our very prosperity depends.
In these difficult times, the only message that should be heard is that European countries can no longer afford the European Union, its institutions and its immense outpourings of legislation.
The crisis has demonstrated that the global financial system is seriously flawed.
First, the supervisory agencies failed to prevent the irresponsible behaviour of investors.
We have seen the development of new financial instruments that are, however, not transparent enough and do not allow for proper risk assessment.
Secondly, owners and shareholders of financial institutions fail to supervise their own managers properly, who pay themselves exorbitant salaries and bonuses. And for what?
forcing their companies to bankruptcy. We need urgent action at least in these two areas.
We do not want a repetition of a scenario of American meltdown, which
We do not want in Europe a situation in which CEOs of financial companies go away with tens of millions of dollars while taxpayers are left there to pay their bills.
We expect the Commission to take serious action on this.

Like the Minister, I have no desire to turn Europe into a fortress, and I want sensible security checks and to use new technology.

But if I can say I have witnessed the use of these passports and I wonder if you can tell me where I am going wrong. What happens, Minister, is that a person in possession of an electronic passport comes up to a machine, places his or her passport on the reader and then walks through if the passport is in order.
I can't see how that is doing anything other than checking that person is in possession of a valid passport.
It does not check that the person has one that has been issued in his or her name.

Therefore, I understand that there would be nothing to stop me from using, Minister, your passport, provided you would lend it to me, using your passport to go through a check, because there is nobody there seeing that the picture or the person is the same, or I could be using the passport of a distinguished person like Mr. Macmillan Scott.
And I wonder if you can give me an assurance of where the check is actually taking place as to the ownership and the actual identity of the person.
Mr. President, I share with my friend and colleague Mr. Skill the delight that we are closing loopholes in this directive,
Timeshare is a big industry, but it can also be a big scam.

For example, I have been dealing with a company called the European Timeshare Owners'Association, which operates in Spain but conveniently from an address in Gibraltar, and I have had constituents tell me that they were approached by this company, which offered to resell their timeshare
When they went to Spain at a great expense, they found that there was no one to buy their timeshare but this company wanted to sell them other timeshare.

I have been trying to get in touch with this company for several weeks and only finally this week managed to do so because miraculously the phone numbers they give do not have people at the other end to answer and they do not seem to respond to letters either.

I hope that we will now start to take action against organizations like the European Timeshare Owners'Organisation, because they give timeshare a bad reputation and, frankly, they damage the image of the Spanish holiday industry, which I know you care so much about.

Mr. President, the Parliament defends individuals and small organisations, small businesses, as opposed to governments that want to sweep away inconvenient things. The Internal Market Committee feels very strongly that external land border shops should be allowed to remain
They should be better policed, just as all police work against crime across borders in Europe should be much better, but it is not a reason to sweep them away.

Secondo, with regard to sea and air travel, the Internal Market Committee firmly believes that travellers whose final destination, in contrast to a transit destination, should be allowed to buy duty free, as this would help small regional airports generate revenue.
It may be inconvenient to governments, but we defend it very strongly.

The third and final point I want to make is that it is very regrettable that the Commission did not include in its consultation on this legislation in 2006 the removal of these exemptions which it is now proposing.
Why didn't it include it?
Why didn't it carry out an impact assessment on what it would mean before proposing it?
Mr. President, it seems as if the Conservatives and Socialists are hand in hand with each other on the Blue Card, leaving my group, to be honest, slowly in amazement.

For some time now, the EU has been trying to come up with a comprehensive package on migration, including measures to tackle illegal migration, as well as measures to push Europe's forward-looking strategy on legal migration.
You may remember the very emotional debate on the Return Directive.

At the time, the ALDE Group said that the return policy cannot be viewed in isolation, that it should be seen as an integral part, a necessary part of a total package on migration, is still very true today.
Today we finally have the chance to give a strong message on the necessity of better possibilities for legal migration, to address the demand of businesses in urgent need of qualified workers,
The fact that we could not expect too much from the PPE on legal migration could, unfortunately, but could in a way be foreseen.
The fact that the EPP is, broadly speaking, happily in line with the EPP on the Blue Card amendments makes my hair stand on end.
Following the vote in the LIBE committee, the scheme has been watered down significantly.
Far too many restrictions have been introduced, which in no way have helped in trying to make the EU more attractive for highly qualified workers.
It must be clear that the intention of the Blue Card is to increase the competitiveness of the EU economy.
The Blue Card proposal is not an easy attempt to take the best and leave the rest, thus creating a brain drain from developing countries.
The current trend is that the vast majority of highly qualified workers emigrate to the USA, Canada or Australia instead of the EU.
If we want to reverse this trend, we have to be ambitious.
This House is about to adopt a report that would further weaken an already very modest Commission proposal.
To be clear, ALDE supports the Blue Card very strongly.
However, we feel that the current text does not bring about the much needed change for legal migration, but rather confirms the protectionist practices of the Member States.

Mr. President, ever since I had the honour of drafting the report on combating HIV/AIDS within the EU and neighboring countries, I have been very committed to this issue with all its implications and ramifications for people living with HIV.
A year ago, as part of the conference HIV in Europe 2007, participants developed a comprehensive call for action on measures to effectively tackle HIV/AIDS in Europe.
Some elements of this call are now also reflected in this joint motion for a resolution.
The aim of this resolution is to contribute to the fight against HIV/AIDS at a political level.

Therefore, it calls on the Council and the Commission to formulate a comprehensive strategy on HIV to promote early diagnosis, ensure early care and communicate the benefits of early care to all European citizens.

It calls on the Commission to commit substantial resources to deliver the above-mentioned strategy, as well as asks Member States to step up information and education campaigns on prevention, testing and treatment.

I am aware that the Commission plans to present a new communication on combating HIV in the EU and the neighbourhood, and also that Commissioner Vassiliou confirmed her personal commitment to take further action in this area.
Concluding, Madam President, this situation needs to be urgently tackled.
A coherent enforcement of environmental legislation is essential for its credibility, for a level playing field and for ensuring that environmental objects will be met.
The issue of environmental inspections is therefore very important for the work of my committee, the Committee on Environment, Public Health and Food Safety.
On November 14, the Commission published the communication on environmental inspections in the Member States.
This communication reviewed the Commission's recommendation 331 from 2001, which provides minimum criteria for environmental inspections.
The communication contains some worrying messages.
It states that the information submitted by the Member States on the implementation of the recommendation is incomplete or difficult to compare.
It states that there are still large differences in the way environmental inspections are carried out in the EU.
It states that the scope of the recommendation is inadequate and that it does not include many important activities such as Natura 2000 and the control of illegal waste shipping.
It states that inspection plans have not been implemented and, where they do exist, that they are often not publicly available.
My committee noted with concern the conclusions of the Commission stating that full implementation of environmental legislation in the community cannot be ensured.
This would not only lead to ongoing damage to the environment, but also to distortion of competition within and between the Member States.
My Committee formulated therefore four questions to the Commission, which can be summarised as follows.
Why does the Commission only wish to amend the recommendation and why does it not propose a directive on environmental inspections?
Secondo, why has the Commission opted instead to attach environmental inspection requirements to existing directives individually, a process that will take a lot of time
Thirdly, why is the Commission not prepared to use a directive to define terms such as inspection and audit, which are interpreted in different ways by Member States?
Fourth, why is the Commission not prepared to transform IMPEL into an effective EU environmental inspection force?
I would like to thank the Commission in advance for their reply and I would like to conclude by emphasising that my opinion, the implementation
and enforcement of environmental legislation should receive the same political attention as the adoption of legislation in the Commission, the Council and the Parliament.

A lotus can be done in the regulation of all financial entities, including hedge funds and private equity funds, limiting leverage, dealing with procyclicality, accounting, better coordinating policies, dealing with rating agencies,

The decline of a paradigm that equates market economies without regulation must be seen in conjunction with a rising multipolar economic world and the attempt to forge a new international financial system.
On the latter hangs the fate of an open world economic system
Unless we do the right things now, we run the risk crippling our liberal democracies.
I hope that the new American administration will be forthcoming in this regard.
But we in Europe must rise to the momentum of this period.

Mr. President, I have just voted on the situation of fundamental rights in the European Union.
It is with great regret that, together with my two Maltese colleagues in the PES, we have had to abstain on the report.
Although the report refers to numerous fundamental human rights issues that are laudable, it includes other issues, such as abortion, which should never have been included in this report.
As the Maltese social representatives in the European Parliament are against abortion, we have had to vote against these particular parts of the report.
Indeed, there are other issues included in this report, such as wills and the right to dignity at the end of life, which are sensitive issues, regarding which we have had to abstain.
That is why we abstained at the end of this vote.
May I thank you for this opportunity.
Mr. President, for all those who have observed the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, this might be a time when we are tempted to raise our hands in the air and scream in despair.
However, I don't think we should, because I think the greatest test of our humanity today is to really understand the issues at hand and
The first issue is that there can be no lasting solution to this conflict without stopping the bombardment of Israel.
The second issue is that there cannot be a lasting solution to this conflict without opening Gaza to humanitarian aid.
President Peres was absolutely right when he said that Gaza should be open for aid and not closed for rockets.
I think this is quintessential and everyone agrees with this.
There can be no return to the status quo ante. I think we could do a number of things here.

Firstly, the Parliament can bring both sides together to talk, secondly, we should stand behind the Commission and the Council and support their efforts, and finally, we should firmly support the Egyptian track of negotiations, because that is the only track that can lead to a solution and a ceasefire, which we all hope for.
I didn't expect that. Mr Vondra, I'm glad to see you back.

Thank you for explaining the gravity of the situation, but when is the Council going to learn that until the EU speaks with one voice on energy issues, particularly in relation to Russia and Ukraine, we are going to be in a weak position?
I'll give you an example where the Council doesn't do that.
We will shortly be starting negotiations on the second reading of the energy liberalisation package.
The Commission has come up with a very carefully drafted position on third countries investing in the EU, suggesting that the Commission speak on behalf of the EU on these issues,
And what have you in the Council done
You have retreated to national positions and said, No, we Member States want the final say, not the Commission.
It is this divide and rule, the oldest trick in the book, that you, Minister, and your colleagues have fallen for.
Until you understand that pooling your powers to gain more leverage internationally is the way to go, we will always be in a position where we are vulnerable
You must answer European citizens as to why they are now sitting in the cold.
You have to change your position on this line.
where internal and regional conflicts continue to undermine peace and security.

Regarding Somalia, I would like to emphasize that the resignation of former President Yousaf and the withdrawal of Ethiopian forces create a huge window of opportunity.

If not, the Ugandan and Burundi forces will pull away from Mogadishu, leaving behind a security gap.
I fully agree with Commissioner Ferreira Waldner
Somalia is now a momentum for change that should be taken advantage of.
The power as well as the security vacuum must be filled
If not, the stateless chaos known as Somalia will remain.

Mr. President, you could have guessed what these reports would say.
We have a problem and the European Union has to give its opinion
It's got to give the impression that it is in the driving seat to solve the problem.
So we have a European economic recovery plan, of which the car industry is a part.
But in reality, each manufacturer will take care of itself as best it can, and each country will take care of its manufacturers as best it can.
Of course, there is a possible case for some support, some financial support to the car industry and other sectors to keep capital intact and to keep skills intact.
But this can only be decided at the national level, because the support, apart from the European Investment Bank mentioned by Mr Verhoeven, can only be provided by national taxpayers.

These environmental and other standard restrictions make cars more expensive

Mr. President, regarding the report on patients'rights in cross-border healthcare, I would like to emphasize the issue of patients'rights to be informed about the available medication and treatment options.

European patients should have access to quality health, information regarding the latest available medication, treatment options in their home and abroad, the legal and financial implications of being treated abroad, reimbursement of treatment costs and many others.
For the moment we do not have this type of quality information.
We may have some national initiatives, but nothing that could be effective at European level.
Problems, which we face, are European.
Therefore, I support the idea of setting up a European health literacy network
Such a network should consist of patient organisations from all Member States and should work closely with the health sector and policymakers.
In the hope of challenging the Commission of the need to better inform the 150 million European patients, I initiated a written declaration on health literacy.
We have all been patients at some point and we never know when it will happen again.

Therefore, I consider that we should refer this report back to the Development Committee in order to agree on a legal basis that has the support of a clear majority of this House.
Mr. President, I welcome this report with just one or two small reservations.
We have heard from my colleague, Mrs Gill, how important small businesses are to the economy and how they bear the brunt of the difficulties of the moment.
Problem is that the European Union is entirely geared for big business, whether it's about legislation or access to markets or about funding
We often talk about better regulation, but what we really mean is proportionality.
We must ensure that our legislation is proportional to the problems we are dealing with, particularly in the IPPCC, which we have discussed today.
It's really about big business, not about small business, and we should reflect that.
I welcome initiatives such as JASMINE, which are moving in the right direction, but we do need to think in terms of funding, market access, legislation, and the specific needs of small businesses.
May I make one particular plea? We have a single market, but we don't have a single Community patent.
We have been dealing with this for years and years and it is really a disgrace that we cannot sort out this problem.
It could by itself be the biggest helpful businesses in the European Union.
Låt oss have some action.

Mr. Commissioner, I welcome the Commission's Green Paper and its objective to increase the visibility of the issues related to the EU health workforce and to identify challenges and further actions that can be taken.
I would like to take the opportunity to emphasize one aspect of the Green Paper, namely the training of the health workforce.
I initiated a written declaration on this issue number ninety five that is ongoing
I strongly support the idea that it is absolutely essential to develop training and communication courses for health workforce in order to provide clearer and more complete information to patients.
The ability of patients to understand health and medical issues and direction are closely related to the clarity of communication.

Despite various initiatives aimed at improving the quality and availability of health information, studies indicate that patients want more information than they currently receive, and that health professionals tend to overestimate the amount of information provided.
Madam President, as you said, on Monday evening the Foreign Affairs Committee adopted a motion regarding the deteriorating humanitarian situation in Sri Lanka in accordance with Rule 91.
The situation in Sri Lanka is clearly very serious, but what exactly is happening with regard to the humanitarian situation is far from clear.
I am aware that there are many different views across this House

I therefore suggest that the most sensible course of action would be to schedule a proper debate, which cannot be seriously fitted in this session, but could be in our next session, which is only ten days away.
I am grateful to Mr. Daul of the EPP for indicating his group's support for this course of action,

And as we are a serious chamber, Madam President, I suggest and ask colleagues to support a debate with resolution and full participation at the next session to do justice to the gravity of the situation in Sri Lanka.
Mr. President, I would like to speak about a very important issue related to the European Prize for Literature.
The Prize is financed by the European Union's Cultural Programme and aims to put the spotlight on creativity in the field of contemporary fiction.
I think it is a very good initiative, but I have my concerns about its implementation.
I have been contacted by cultural organizations from my country who are unhappy because Romania is not included in the program this year.
Indeed, only twelve of the thirty four eligible countries are included each year in this programme.
The legitimate question is how the remaining countries, including Romania, could take an active part if they are not included in the program at all?
So I would like to bring this problem to your attention and I hope we will find, together with the Commission, a convenient manner to settle this problem.

Mr. President, what worries me the most is the suggestion that the European Investment Bank has a significant role to play in solving the financial crisis, that it can somehow act as the Europe-wide body to provide stimulus where Member States have singularly failed to coordinate their own stimuli.

The danger is that if it expands its activities too far into supporting commercial banks and governments, as has been suggested, then its enviable high credit rating may be downgraded like some of our governments.
The EIB has a leverage of about 35 times and its shareholders are Member State governments.
It would be a serious issue if it were to go bankrupt, like some of our commercial banks.
The report even encourages the EIB and the Commission to increase lending by experimenting with new innovative financial instruments.
I thought the world had seen enough of clever financial tricks.
Mr. President, in this budget review, we simply have to ask ourselves one question. Does the budget reflect the political priorities of the 21st century?
If it doesn't, it needs to be changed.
Is it flexible enough to reflect changing times?
because one of my frustration at the moment with the budget is how we deal with negative priorities
Too much is left in the budget because we cannot change things because of the restrictions of the MFF.

If I could turn to activity-based budgeting and management, I think the Commission has made huge progress on this, but I would warn against overbureaucratizing this exercise, because what we want to ensure is a qualitative evaluation, not just ticking boxes.
We do not want people to spend all their time evaluating themselves when they should be getting on and doing some work.
So we've got to be careful about that.
I personally believe that the annual policy strategy would be better if it were every two or every two and a half years to fit into the parliamentary cycle
This will allow us to get a much clearer idea of our policy perspectives, in addition to the Commission's annual work programs.
Commissioner, I would like to speak about the Van Nistelrooy report and emphasise three points.
First, territorial cohesion involves promoting policentric development throughout the European Union.
This means eliminating disparities within and between regions.
Consequently, there is a need for improved spatial analysis and the development of indicators against which policies can be designed and their impact assessed.
Secondly, there must be an integrated approach, with measurement in advance of the effect that sectoral policies would have at regional levels and the achievement of greater synergy between them.
Of course, such impact assessment could prevent certain problems, such as those posed by the electronic identification of sheep in Scotland.
Thirdly, an integrated approach requires proper multi-level governance involving all stakeholders in the design and implementation of strategies.
What the Commissioner said in this regard has been very welcome, and I hope for great support for this excellent report.
Mr. President of the Commission, Minister, I would like to first thank the Czech Presidency for the successful summit
I think the summit has come up with a number of important decisions, but at the same time I am of the opinion that we need more and we need to move faster.

Mr. President, this energy package is the culmination of years of hard work in which Parliament can be very proud of the changes that will now be implemented.

We should be particularly proud of the fact that EU energy consumers have now been put right at the center of the energy debate for the first time, and the issue of energy poverty has now been recognized at European level.

The inherent conflict of interest that arises when a company owns both transmission and generation of electricity has been addressed, and the regulatory regime governing the energy markets has been strengthened.

The Electricity Directive, for which I was rapporteur, is part of a package of five measures that seeks improvements in the way electricity and gas markets work across the continent to ensure that the markets are better integrated and operate in a fairer and less discriminatory way.

I would like to express how grateful I have been for the enormous cooperation of the other rapporteurs on this package, including the shadows, the Commission and the Czech Presidency, for helping us to come to a conclusion on what was sometimes a very challenging debate.

The legislation has seen a raft of new consumer protection measures set out, including ensuring that customers can switch suppliers within three weeks, the provision in each Member State of an independent and robust complaint system and the right to compensation if service levels are not met.
This legislation has also ensured that every household in the EU will be fitted with so-called smart meters by 2022.
These smart meters will enable customers to better control their energy use and increase energy efficiency, helping to cut energy costs and reduce carbon emissions.

On the Parliament's initiative, the new legislation also includes special protection measures for vulnerable energy consumers, and the issue of energy poverty will now have to be taken seriously for the first time.
I would like to ask Commissioner Piebalgs if he will now make a commitment that in the future the energy framework of the EU, in addition to addressing
Security of supply, sustainability and competitiveness will now also add a fourth leg, that of affordability to all future energy policy proposals.
AU-supported report has recently concluded that up to 125 million citizens are affected by energy poverty.
Member States must now take appropriate measures, which could lead to the prevention of hundreds, if not thousands, of deaths in the poorest households across the continent.
We will also see the end of discriminatory pricing on prepayment meters.

The most controversial part of the package was centered on whether there was a need for full ownership unbundling in the energy markets, in other words, a total separation of transmission systems from generation.

The market structure in some Member States means that the monopoly enjoyed by transmission system operators who also own the means of generating electricity does not offer any incentive to encourage other players to enter the market, thereby undermining competition.

The Parliament has now accepted a compromise that will allow ownership of both transmission and generation on the condition that we see increased checks and balances to ensure the removal of the inherent conflict of interest that arises.

Many of us reluctantly accepted the compromise because we believe that the wind is blowing in the direction of wholesale separations, and these integrated companies are likely to separate regardless of this directive.

The Commission's efforts to expose the abuses of some companies are starting to pay off, with examples of companies like E.ON and RWE agreeing to sell their transmission networks following antitrust investigations.
We are also going to see a strengthening of national regulatory authorities
I would like to thank everybody for their cooperation and I think we should be proud of what we have done for the consumers of the EU.

Mr. President, the international community has been absolutely appalled by the information that we have all seen about the law that is being drafted in Afghanistan on the status of Shia women.

It is indeed appalling to believe that at the beginning of the 21st century, in a country that wants to be a democracy and wants to comply with its international commitments, one can have a law that limits women's rights.
Ωστόσο, in our debate and in everything we do with Afghanistan, we must be very careful how we approach things. Afghanistan is a country that comes through a violent
It is a repressive religious dictatorship. It has endured years and years and decades of civil war. It is a society in which people have been hurt and destroyed more than buildings.
We must be very consistent in our messages, but we must also be very careful in how we phrase those messages.
We should call on the Afghan authorities to take a look at the law, revise it and make sure it is entirely in line with the international commitments of that country, as well as its constitution.

We should not use this as an election opportunity here for us in Europe, but we should use it as something that we can pass on to our colleagues and friends in Afghanistan to make sure that they can actually fulfill the obligations that they have voluntarily undertaken themselves.
In this case, we must assist President Karzai and the Afghan government in revisiting this law and ensuring that it is in line with international commitments and the constitution.
It is part of our dialog. We must be absolutely firm that there should be no measures adopted that can actually impede the rights of women.
I fully agree with what Ms Anna Gomes just said.
But let's be very careful that when we deal with a society that has been so traumatised, it is far more important how our messages are heard there than how our messages are understood here.
Let us be very consistent in this and let us call on the Commission and the Council to pass this message through all of our assistance programmes to the government and the authorities in Afghanistan.

Mr. President, esteemed colleagues, the situation in Camp Ashraf, where live three members of the main democratic opposition of Iran, the PMOI, has been of great concern for some time and has been the subject of several resolutions in this House in recent years.
Together with a delegation of four Members of this House visited Camp Ashraf in October last year and met with American, Iraqi and UN officials there.
They all reinforced our concern for the legal status of Asraf's residents, because security was transferred from American troops to Iraqi forces from the beginning of this year.
Situation eroded much worse since then.
In a formal announcement at the end of February, the Iranian supreme leader asked the Iraqi president to implement the mutual agreement to close down Camp Ashraf and expel all residents from Iraq.
Since then, a search and surrounding by Iraqi forces has started around the camp.

Iraqi troops have prevented the entry of families of Ashraf residents, parliamentary delegations, human rights organizations, lawyers, journalists and even doctors into the camp and do not allow many logistical materials to enter Ashraf.
This Parliament found it absolut necessary to address this as an urgent issue at this stage.

We have now worked together with all groups and produced a common text that is well balanced and addresses all our concerns on this matter and calls on international bodies to find a long term legal status for Ashraf residents.
Unfortunately, some amendments tabled by some of the spokesmen for Tehran, those who believe in the lies told by Tehran
I think we should clearly understand that this is contrary to the security of the residents of Ashraf and we should vote against them.
We urge all colleagues to stick to the joint text and reject any amendments
Mr. President, on behalf of one of my constituents, I want to raise the case of a young man with dual British Greek nationality. His name is John Zafiropoulos.
Last year he was convicted by a Greek court of first degree for serving an unconsiderably severe sentence in prison in Greece.
From the information I have been given, Mr President, I consider that the crucial rules relating to Greek legislation, as well as the provisions for fair trials, have been violated.
These provisions on fair trial are defined by all of Europe and are the rights of every European citizen.
At the beginning of this year I wrote to the Greek Minister of Justice in Athens to alert him about my concerns.

The response I received three months later was signed by minor ministry employees and did not refer to the matter I had raised with the minister, in other words, the breaking of the rules about fair trials.

I am very concerned about this, Mr President, and for this reason I am raising the issue in Parliament right now, hoping that Athens will both send me a proper reply and will provide a full and fair review of the case of Mr Zafiropoulos.

Mr. President, after fifteen years this will be my last speech in the European Parliament, and I think there are few more important issues than the whole question of asylum and how European countries face this challenge.
There is no easy response to this issue either.
If there was, some country would have founded it by now.

In reality, I would suggest that the only way to reduce the number of desperate people who seek refuge or asylum in a country other than their own is to address the root causes that force them to leave their homes and their country of origin.

That is why it is so important that we in the EU and in all developed democratic countries offer advice, help and support, including financial support, to those countries that are affected by war, internal violence, lack of human rights or discrimination.
Equally, we have to address the poverty around the world, which contributes to migratory pressures.
We should never condemn people who are forced to seek asylum or refugee status
Instead, we should offer sympathy and offer our support.
That today, colleagues, is our challenge. Thank you, Mr President,

Madam President, Commissioner Piebalgs, the question was submitted by Brian Simpson on behalf of the Parliament's Committee on Transport and Tourism following the Commission's report examining the effectiveness of the EU blacklist.
The EU blacklist was established in 2006 to name, shame and ban airlines that do not comply with international safety rules.
It was established in response to concerns about the level of enforcement of international safety standards and following several fatal air crashes over a short period of time in 2004 and 2005.
Four Years on, we know that the Black List has proven to be an effective and valuable tool in promoting and enforcing ICAO safety standards and protecting EU citizens.
How can we build on this is the question facing us today.
In other words, how can we extend the protection beyond our own borders and further work towards the goal of improving global aviation security?
The Blacklist has the responsibility not only to identify where the safety risks lie, but also to ensure that this information is effectively communicated to EU citizens.
In line with this, how can we ensure that EU citizens taking flights outside of Europe are aware of banned air carriers that continue to operate in other regions of the world?
In cases where the air carrier's license has been revoked and thereby the air carrier does not appear on the blacklist, how can we be sure that passengers are aware of this situation?
We have seen how effective it has been to bring together the different national blacklists into one comprehensive EU-wide list.
However, the blacklist is only as good as the access we have to information relating to the safety of aircouriers.
How can we build on the information that forms the basis of the blacklist by improving access to verifiable and reliable information?
This means not only strengthening the checks carried out in EU Member States, but also improving the data information received from non-EU Member States.
Would the Commission consider establishing harmonised and standardised ramp checks and reporting?

In terms of improving the data information received from third countries, would the Commission consider establishing an effective system of international exchange of reliable data, bringing us closer to a kind of worldwide blacklist, which I know has been mooted in the past?
Furthermore, it is worth pointing out that the blacklist has proven to be an effective tool in incentivizing airlines to meet international safety standards.
But how can we more proactively work towards the ultimate goal of improving global aviation safety?
I mean how the Commission intends to support national civil aviation authorities in meeting safety deficits based on ICAO audits and in improving their oversight capabilities.

It is crucial that we ensure effective communication channels with the public, but it is also vitally important that we continue to work on promoting the enforcement of international aviation safety standards around the world in the long term.
This will ultimately be the most effective way to improve safety for all passengers.
The Transport and Tourism Committee of the European Parliament is looking forward to working with the Commission to try to build on the EU's Blacklist achievements.

Mr. President, better and less expensive data transmissions through high-speed broadband for all in 2020. This is an ambitious policy target, I must say, and I fully support it.
But, priznajmo, it won't come easily.
Nevertheless, I believe that with the Parliament's first reading position we will be able to take a big first step towards this goal.
Let's be clear. Broadband for All is not just about making sure that everyone has a Facebook profile.
The aim is to ensure Europe's place in the world as a leading knowledge-based economy.
If we manage to connect 500 million people, our citizens and businesses will be able to reap all the benefits and opportunities of the digital economy.
Two things need to change for Europe to get there.
Firstly, we need a well-functioning pro-competition telecommunications market at European level.
That is why we have introduced rules on competition proofing.
Member States should not be allowed to allocate newly freed up spectrum to a specific market player if that would diminish or distort competition in the market.
Secondly, we need a more efficient allocation of spectrum, an allocation that also more accurately reflects today's diverse demands and needs for spectrum.
That is why we are gearing this policy program not only to free up the 800 MHz band, but also to free up additional bands amounting to at least 1200 MHz by 2015.

Let me finish by thanking the Commission, the Commissioner, the rapporteur and my fellow shadows for an extraordinary good cooperation. Without it, this level of ambition would not have been possible.
President, it has often been said that our citizens are unaware of the greater powers that this Parliament has since Lisbon.
This may be true and it is very unfortunate, because rest assured that lobbyists or those pretending to be lobbyists, as recently proven, are very well aware of the powers of this Parliament.
We co-decide on almost every major legislation in the EU, and that is a good thing because we represent the people of the EU
We are the only directly elected body for them.

Now, although this is and will remain one of the most transparent institutions in the Union, I still believe that with greater power comes greater responsibility, and this is precisely what we must strive to achieve in the coming months.
Today's agreement with the Commission is not bad, but lobbyists must be obliged to put their names and their real interests in a register.
And this is what this Parliament is already demanding from lobbyists coming here to us.
I hope that the other institutions will follow suit.
I close by saying the following. As you mentioned, I am co-president of this working group that we have in place
I cannot say much about what we are discussing in detail.

I can assure you, however, that we will ensure that the rules of conduct for this Parliament will be among the most transparent and among those that can make our citizens and ourselves proud to be members of this extraordinary institution.
Thank you.

I hope everyone agrees that the constitution must be balanced, close to the citizens, based on generally accepted values and principles and should be partially neutral.
Sadly, the Hungarian constitution does not fulfill these criteria.
Even adoption of the document is questionable.
There was no or very little social consultation.
The text is supported only by one political party and is opposed by major constitutional experts.
The new constitution raises questions at an international level,
For example, there is a lack of reference to EU law in the closure.
Note clear differences when comparing the text with the Charter of Fundamental Rights, textual inconsistencies and differences in values and principles.
The princip of good governance does not prevail in the document either.
The Constitution fails to provide an EU-compliant modern administrative structure.
The aforementioned generic laws are very dangerous.
They make governing the country almost impossible for any future government.
We have the impression, as one of our colleagues has put it, that the government is like a football team trying to change the rules and the referee during a game.
